DOC.HEAD: City in Chaos: Looting and a Vow to Keep Up the Fight
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dodging gunfire and patrols of both U.S. troops and Panamanian militia, civilians took to the streets of a city in chaos and enthusiastically looted everything from jewelry stores to appliance shops. A festive atmosphere reigned Wednesday in commercial districts as civilians walked away with cameras, tires, mattresses, even refrigerators and stoves carried by four or five people at a time. As midday temperatures hovered at 99 degrees, Red Cross teams scurried to pick up bodies from the pre-dawn fighting before they decomposed in the heat. Men, women and children emerged from the low-income area of Chorillo and Old Panama, where combat was especially intense, and walked to churches, hospitals and schools in search of safety. Some cursed the U.S. troops, others Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Still others said they had faith in the strongman's powers of survival. ``They (the Americans) have been very tough with this invasion, and the poorer people had to suffer most,'' said Juan, about 25 years old, as he and a group of friends fended off the heat with cold beers a few yards from the Old Panama barracks, destroyed by American troops. ``If you keep standing in the middle of the street, the `gringos' are going to arrest you,'' Juan warned a reporter. About half a dozen American soldiers sat on a roadside patch of grass about 20 yards away. The GIs appeared nervous as they took a break to eat lunch. A few blocks away, a housewife of about 40 looked happily at the American troops. ``There was no other way to get this bandit out,'' she said of Noriega. A man of about 25, with unkempt hair, spray-painted a nearby wall: ``Sovereignty Without Noriega!'' Armed toughs who support Noriega took advantage of the chaos to commandeer cars, often at gunpoint. Attack jets bombed and helicopters strafed a Panamanian Defense Forces barracks on a hill in the San Miguelito neighborhood to the northeast, a stronghold of the Dignity Battalions _ the armed militia loyal to Noriega. One man who said he was a government employee stood at a newsstand near the Foreign Ministry building. About 35, he refused to give his name but said he had confidence in Noriega. ``The MAN,'' he said, referring to the general by his nickname, ``he's going to resist and things are going to get tough for the Yankees. He knows what he's doing.'' At dozens of U.S. Army checkpoints, those who wanted to pass had to get out of their cars and drop to their knees while their vehicles were thoroughly searched. In one house, where four reporters were hiding along with the residents, the owner said he had nothing to fear until his wife noticed an 8-by-10 color photo of her husband as a student shaking hands with Cuban President Fidel Castro. She swiftly hid the photo in their bedroom.
